thread.title: Oregon labor commissioner announces run for secretary of state
thread.title_full: Oregon labor commissioner announces run for secretary of state | OregonLive.com

author: Denis C. Theriault | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Oregon labor commissioner announces run for secretary of state
text:
Oregon's labor commissioner — Brad Avakian, who made news this year for taking on a Gresham bakery that refused to serve a same-sex wedding — made official Monday his plans to run for secretary of state in 2016.
Avakian, who'd been laying the groundwork for a run for weeks , is t he second high-profile Democrat to formally declare for the office. He follows Sen. Richard Devlin of Tualatin, an influential co-chair of the Legislature's budget committee.
The office oversees the state's elections system, auditors and corporation registry, among other roles. The secretary of state also sits on the State Land Board, which weighs the fate of natural resources including Oregon's forests, coastal lands and rivers.
And, as Oregonians were reminded when then-Secretary of State Kate Brown took over for Gov. John Kitzhaber in February, whoever holds the office is first in line to succeed a governor who leaves office.
"I'm running to be the kind of active, progressive leader that Oregonians need on the priorities that are so important to our future," he said in a statement that also mentioned his interest in expanding vocational education in Oregon schools. "Increasing corporate accountability in the workplace, using a wider range of tools to create jobs and combating climate change are just a few of the areas where this job can lead the way."
Another leading Democrat, Rep. Val Hoyle of Eugene, also is expected to run for the office. Hoyle stepped down as House majority leader in July to kick the tires on a statewide campaign.
The three-way battle is shaping up as the most compelling statewide race on next May's primary ballot. No big-name Democrat has signaled interest in challenging Brown when she runs for the last two years of Kitzhaber's fourth term. Rep. Tobias Read of Beaverton also is running unopposed in the Democratic primary for state treasurer.
Hoyle will have to give up a run for re-election to the House. Devlin and Avakian, both in the middle of four-year terms, can keep their current posts if they lose next year.
Avakian, head of the Bureau of Labor and Industries for the past seven years, is charged with investigating complaints against employers and civil rights complaints involving businesses.
And he's used his power to wade into controversial issues — including ordering Gresham bakery Sweet Cakes for Melissa to pay a lesbian couple $135,000 in damages over its refusal to bake a wedding cake.
In 2013, he fined a North Portland bar accused of banning transgender patrons. And he obtained a $2.4 million settlement against Daimler Trucks after employees at the company's Swan Island complained about racial and gay slurs, Nazi graffiti and harassment . Avakian has also advocated for raising the state's minimum wage.
The work has kept Avakian in headlines, earning him exposure and some name recognition. But he's also been raising large sums of money this year, with his campaign reporting more than $170,000 in cash on hand. Devlin, thanks to past campaigns, has nearly $300,000 available.
So far, just one Republican has declared for secretary of state, Lane County Commissioner Sid Leiken , who had initially said he was exploring a run for governor.
